comment._content: Found reference to an article by a Miss J. Marchal, "Infectious Ectromelia: A Hitherto Undescribed Virus Disease of Mice," Journal of Pathology and Bacteriology 33(3)(1930): 713-728. (She's thanked as Miss Marchal in another article from the 1930s, for providing samples of ectromelia virus.) At the paper was published in 1930, this Miss Marchal was affiliated with the National Institute for Medical Research, Hampstead, London. The Encyclopedia of Toxicology credits Marchal with discovering the ectromelia virus in 1930. It's also called "mousepox." There are things called Marchal bodies associated with ectromelia, probably named for her. She's listed as Miss J. E. Marchal in the 1930 Report of the Medical Research Council of Great Britain (on Google Books). And she's listed as one of many coauthors on the "Reports on Biological Standards Vol. 5," from the Medical Research Council (1932, also on Google Books). (And now I've seen enough photos of pox-ridden mice to last me a lifetime, thank you.)
